Abstract: This review explores the emerging field of electrically controllable materials for soft, bioinspired machines. We examine recent advancements in soft robotics, focusing on actuators and robotic materials that mimic biological systems. The integration of multifunctional materials with electrical control mechanisms has led to significant progress in creating more adaptable and responsive soft robots. We discuss various types of electrically-driven actuators, including dielectric elastomers, ionic polymer-metal composites, and shape memory alloys, highlighting their unique properties and potential applications. Additionally, we analyze the challenges and opportunities in developing bioinspired soft machines that can seamlessly interact with their environment. This review provides insights into the current state of the art and future directions for electrically controllable materials in soft robotics, emphasizing their potential to revolutionize fields such as healthcare, environmental monitoring, and human-robot interaction.
